TopicTitle: The thread for all things Curiosity related

Articles.Content: YAY! It isn't a 2.5 Billion dollar Mistake that the public will hold over NASA's head!
Yes! Loved the mission controller's look of relief
That was amazing. Good job NASA, nothing less than perfect trip.

[ATTACH=CONFIG]30802[/ATTACH]

Open up a pack of beer... Cheers..

Got some screens of the 3D simulation, figured someone might want to see it.

Also have one from when it was 2 hours away, but image limit is 5
double streamin on my moms crappy laptop. arrgh
I've had some tense moments in my life, but that was just ridiculous.
hooray for a good landing! Exciting times ahead.

I've had some tense moments in my life, but that was just ridiculous.

This peaks up there close to the end of season 6 of Americas Got Talent.
Didn't know there was an HD stream, so here's a crappy SD screencap:

Heres a picture of the camera!

now lets have KSP with 256x256 BW cameras to show us pictures of our lander's shadow with minutes of delays before seeing them!
0.00456m/s horizontal velocity. New Kerbal challenge, try to beat that!

0.00456m/s horizontal velocity. New Kerbal challenge, try to beat that!

I'm really glad I wasn't the only one to think that...
Who just listenened to the post mission poll? Negative 0.946582 vertical landing speed and 0.04663648 Horizontal speed. thats about 1000 times better than my best KSP landing.
The first images are blurry because the lens cap is still on protecting the cameras. They will open the caps and take better pictures soon
0.00456 m/s? Heck, I think my rocket on the launch pad is moving faster than that!
This truly is a great achievement.

Courtasy of Nomad, who's having login issues:

https://dl.dropbox.com/u/16349584/curiosity2.PNG
Fuuu did you see those landing values? Im usually about 5m/s hori./vert. And i usually tip over and have to panic to save it lol. Awesome job NASA!
What the heck does a negative vertical landing speed mean?
It means you are slowly losing altitude.

I have the raw 256X256 front hazcam image showing the rover's shadow, can't attach to the post though because of size. I'm not going to commentate, because anything I say would be inadequate to describe how awesome this is. Did anyone else grab any images before Nasa's servers went down?
Goodnight everyone that was a epic 3 hours. Thanks KSP forums for letting me communicate with everyone and have a great time, goodnight.
Curiosity has landed less than 250 meters from the point set !!!

Nice start for the week.

Good job nasa!
